misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No misconception detected (correct parallel-array sort and selection)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array while performing the same swaps on the `names` array will keep each name aligned with its corresponding score, and that after an ascending sort the last element holds the highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no gap here: in Java, arrays are indexed collections, and swapping both arrays at the same indices during sorting correctly preserves the name–score pairing. After sorting ascending, index `N-1` is indeed the maximum score (for N>0).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None for valid inputs where N>0 and scores are provided as integers. Output matches the specification and sample run.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[N - 1];
int top_score = scores_array[N - 1];

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming a non-empty array when taking the maximum
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes there will always be at least one student (N >= 1), so accessing index N-1 is always safe.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed and an array of length 0 has no valid indices. If N can be 0, then N-1 is -1 and any access like names[N-1] will throw an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Correct programs either constrain/validate input (require N>=1) or handle N==0 explicitly before indexing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) if N == 0. Otherwise, correct output.
